title: Besu 22.1.0-RC4 loses ability to respond to websocket
body:
### Description

Besu v22.1.0-RC4 loses the ability to respond to websocket connections. Eventually it will start displaying blocked thread messages in a continuous loop. Restart resolves it, until it re-occurs.

This is while using Bonsai tries.

I had this issue with the current GA release as well and tried 22.1.0-RC4 for the sync fixes. This issue here does not appear related to sync at all: Besu does not have to do a lengthy catchup after restart.

When this happens, Besu does not respond gracefully to SIGTERM.

**Frequency:**

Reproducible by using Besu as the WS target of a chainlink node

### Versions
* Software version: besu/v22.1.0-RC4/linux-x86_64/openjdk-java-11
* OS Name & Version: Ubuntu 20.04
* Docker Version: 20.10.7

Besu is configured with `--Xdata-storage-format=BONSAI`

### System

6-core, 32 GiB RAM, 1.9TB NVMe
Do you have reason to believe this is specific to bonsai?  What web socket client are you using, nimbus?

I have no reason to believe this is in any way related to Bonsai. I mention it because it's still an experimental flag, but I don't think it has anything to do with this failure mode.

The websocket client is a chainlink node.

@yorickdowne please try to catch a thread dump, in case it should happen again. 
See https://www.baeldung.com/java-thread-dump in case you need instructions.

I've added `-XX:+UnlockDiagnosticVMOptions -XX:+LogVMOutput -XX:LogFile=/var/lib/besu/jvm.log` to `JAVA_OPTS` and will `kill -3` Besu when this happens again.

After pointing the chainlink node at it, I immediately see

Let me see what `kill -3` gets me. Log attached. @fab-10 

[jvm.log](https://github.com/hyperledger/besu/files/8016813/jvm.log)

When this happens, haproxy marks the Besu node as down and fails over to a Geth instance. haproxy does a liveness test via RPC, not WS, which suggests that both WS and RPC are down at that point. These messages do not stop until Besu has been restarted. To keep them from immediately occuring again, Besu cannot be the primary target of haproxy and thus the chainlink node.

thanks for the logs @yorickdowne, we will review them.
To help us reproducing this problem, do you which kind of requests, and the how many in parallel, Chainlink submits to Besu?
Let me try something - I can point chainlink at Infura (the horror!) and see what gets recorded.

Roughly 10 minutes worth of requests. The bulk appears to be `eth_call`
